title: Dick Barone
text:
Richard Anthony Barone (October 13, 1932 – April 23, 2015) was an <a href="Americans">American</a> <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a>. A <a href="shortstop">shortstop</a> and <a href="second%20baseman">second baseman</a>, he played for a decade in <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league baseball</a>, and had a three-game <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">major league</a> career with the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a>. The native of <a href="San%20Jose%2C%20California">San Jose, California</a>, threw and batted <a href="right-handed">right-handed</a>, stood tall and weighed . He was the <a href="grandfather">grandfather</a> of former major league <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> <a href="Daniel%20Barone%20%28baseball%29">Daniel Barone</a>.
Barone was in his eighth season of pro ball when the Pirates called him up in September 1960, when <a href="MLB%20rosters">MLB rosters</a> expand to 40 players. He had <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batted</a> .204 in 143 <a href="games%20played">games played</a> for the <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a> <a href="Columbus%20Jets">Columbus Jets</a> of the <a href="International%20League">International League</a>. The <a href="1960%20Pittsburgh%20Pirates%20season">1960 Pirates</a> were en route to their first <a href="National%20League">National League</a> title since . Barone debuted as a <a href="pinch%20runner">pinch runner</a> for 42-year-old <a href="player-coach">player-coach</a> <a href="Mickey%20Vernon">Mickey Vernon</a> on September 22 in the ninth <a href="inning%20%28baseball%29">inning</a> of a 2–2 game against the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a>, but did not score in a contest eventually won by Pittsburgh, 3–2 in 11 innings. The Pirates clinched the pennant three days later, on September 25.
On September 27, Barone started his only major league game. Playing <a href="shortstop">shortstop</a> against the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a>, he played <a href="error%20%28baseball%29">errorless</a> ball in the field, handling five <a href="chance%20%28baseball%29">chances</a>, and went <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hitless</a> in five <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a> and five <a href="plate%20appearances">plate appearances</a> against the Reds' <a href="pitchers">pitchers</a> <a href="Bob%20Purkey">Bob Purkey</a>, <a href="Orlando%20Pe%C3%B1a">Orlando Peña</a> and <a href="Cal%20McLish">Cal McLish</a>. It was another extra-inning game: Barone played the first 13 innings before he was removed for <a href="pinch%20hitter">pinch hitter</a> <a href="Smoky%20Burgess">Smoky Burgess</a>. The Pirates prevailed, 4–3, in 16 innings.
On September 30, Barone appeared in his last major league contest as a late-inning defensive replacement, also making a <a href="batted%20ball">fly ball</a> <a href="out%20%28baseball%29">out</a> in one at bat against <a href="Bob%20Buhl">Bob Buhl</a> of the <a href="Milwaukee%20Braves">Milwaukee Braves</a>. He was not on the Pirates' <a href="1960%20World%20Series">1960 World Series</a> roster.
Barone played two more seasons of minor league baseball before retiring after the 1962 campaign.
